Expectation1: Offer help or support when asked
Situation1: An acquaintance asks for a recommendation on a good restaurant in the area.
Expectation2: Contribute to community well-being through paying taxes, following public health and safety guidance, and helping in emergencies
Situation2: A heat advisory is issued for the day and an elderly neighbor on the floor lives alone.
Story:
I was just about to head out for lunch when my phone buzzed. It was Mark, an old college acquaintance who’d recently moved to town. “Hey, do you know any good restaurants nearby?” he texted. As an acquaintance, I felt I should help him settle in, maybe even join him for a meal. I started typing out a few suggestions, thinking about which places had the best food and atmosphere.

But then, I remembered the heat advisory that had been issued this morning. The news had warned everyone to check on vulnerable neighbors, especially the elderly. Mrs. Lee, who lived alone down the hall, came to mind. As a responsible citizen, I knew I should check on her, maybe bring her some cold water or help her set up her fan. The city’s message was clear: look out for each other, especially during emergencies.

I stared at my phone, torn. Mark was waiting for my reply, and I didn’t want to let him down. But the thought of Mrs. Lee alone in her apartment, possibly struggling with the heat, gnawed at me. I felt the weight of both expectations pressing in, unsure which role I should fulfill first.
